job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Seattle, WA
pros:
Worked on the Amazon Search Services team (AWS), most notably providing Amazon Elasticsearch Service.

The work was challenging and full of operational puzzles, metrics to contemplate, glitches to find, fires to put out, and resources to optimize.

If you agree with "Amazon Leadership Principles" (which I do), you have the opportunity to do things that really align with them. "Customer Obsession" was always my favorite.

The only variable was management, which in my experience was binary: Top notch, and ... "Sauron." Believe me you don't want Option B.
cons:
Amazon comp is always a little on the low side, until you reach Director or equivalent (L7-8). It can be very low relative to other opportunities if you were unlucky when hired.

Great management at AWS is great and the work is great too.

The right (wrong) management will stop you cold, and there is nothing you can do about it. Transfer may or may not be possible.

Life-work balance again is one of those things that can be terrific (retail is better than AWS!) or horrific. Our team, from the first to last day I worked there (4-1/2 years) had a horrific operational burden and on-call (software engineers always have on-call periods for their service/product) was a recurring, unavoidable nightmare. However, other teams have great on-call experiences, as in, hardly noticed. Luck of the draw. Ask.

The promotion process is idiotic. Essentially, employees write their own promotion document, and management mulls it over. I never thought it was 1) a good use of my time, or 2) fun to sit around tooting my own horn when I could be doing useful work.

Everyone at a certain level and above has the same base salary. "Real" compensation is determined by RSU grants above that. This is essentially solely at the discretion of a couple levels of management. Same job title, same work, same effectiveness, sitting next to each other, two people can be making 50% different money. It's all decided by fairness or whim.

pros:
* Super smart people

* Bad work-life balance

* unrealistic expectations from employees
* extreme operational load. Too little software engineering, and too much of dealing with fires in legacy systems.
* management is too focused on deliver results and frugality, and not in any other leadership principle. If you show good ownership or high standards, that won't matter in your performance review.
* management doesn't care about your career path, and your own interests. You'll be assigned tasks that don't motivate you forever, because people with more tenure in the team will be able to finish "interesting tasks" faster.
* Performance reviews are not fair: you might get bad performance just because someone needs to get it, even if you meet all the required criteria for a good performance
* Compensation adjustment is not fair: you'll find people in the exact same position and team as you, who were hired some months later, and they earn between 10% and 35% more. Even if you have the maximum performance possible, your increase in one year won't be more than 5%, so you will need to be working 10 hours per day for 5 years to reach the same compensation.
* no flexibility in terms of time off: management will reject petitions to work from another city/country, take more than 2 weeks in a row of vacation, or change oncall shifts to allow you to travel.
* very little perks compared to other tech companies (no food, no gym, small discount, almost nothing can be expensed)
* for a place that calls itself inclusive, there are less than 10 women, and no black people in a team of ~100.

why? because you've entered an abusive relationship with an entity that is already getting what it wants from you and has no incentive to consider your well being . You are more than replaceable. review_title: Not the place to be for experienced recruiters
pros:
1. Flexible work schedule that is hourly for recruiting coordinators: Can work 8 hours in your time zone as long as you cover 7am-3pm.

2. Because it's "hourly" you get paid weekly and can avoid being overworked.

3. The benefits are so good because of how huge the company is.

4. I did have a wonderful team and manager that genuinely cared about me.
cons:
1. The entire talent acquisition organization is a hot mess. None of the recruiting lanes have the same procedures and duties. Every person's work is defined differently and takes on different duties. Doesn't seem like a big deal until you're helping someone that supports a different lane from you and it takes you an extra 30 minutes to an hour to schedule on their jobs because procedures are that different. 

2. There is SO MUCH turnover and movement in both senior management and at the individual level. This makes it difficult to keep procedures in place and even define who does what. 

3. Training is spotty, unorganized, and dependent on you having a good team and "onboarding buddy." Many things are repeated while others are left out. No basic training manual that is organized for everyone. 

4. Your success and experience is LARGELY determined by your manager. To even get promoted (the ONLY way you get paid more) is for your manager to write a 6 page paper. Amazon really loves papers for anything you want to suggest/change, and honestly this doesn't help push change along. 

5. Career progression is not as promised. In a recruiting coordinator role the only way to progress is to move to another role (like a recruiter for example). You must interview internally for the same level position you enter at. Meaning you have to interview (another 4 hours of straight behavioral interviewing) for another level 4 position (level 4 is the only level you can be hired at as a recruiting coordinator). This seems fine, until you find out you will get paid the SAME in the new role, even though you're working harder, are likely now base salaried (no overtime), and have different responsibilities. This makes ZERO sense. The worst part: if they hired you as a level 4 sourcing recruiter role from the outside, they would pay you $20k-$30k more! Why would I stay and interview internally to get paid the same as someone hired from the outside. They are really not set up for keeping people and growing them within the company.

6. Annual "compensation" review is not what is pitched during interview. This year almost none of the recruiters got a pay raise, even with great reviews, because Amazon argued that the stock went up so their overall compensation increased. Funny thing is, the average tenure of a recruiting coordinator is 11 months, yet the stock doesn't fully vest for 4 years. So you're not making more money when the stock goes up, because you don't own the stock yet. The problem is they pitch that there is a raise, and yet the results are not the same. 

7. If you're conservative, run. This is an extremely liberal company. In the pursuit of being diverse and inclusive, Amazon has taken it WAY too far. They're very exclusive to anyone that is not liberal. If you're liberal, you'll probably love it.

8. A lot of time is being wasted on duplicate efforts. Seems like there is a D&I team in every department and on every team. And the same could be said on many other efforts. Amazon is big enough to have entire departments spearheading these efforts, yet everyone else is trying to make teams and committees to also do things. It's a waste of time and energy on everyone's part.

9. Compensation is not competitive with other companies in the market. The sign on bonuses seem great at first, until you realize the only way you'll make more money once those are up is to get promoted. 

10. The interview process to get into Amazon is so bad. You spend 2 hours doing only behavioral interviewing and get maybe 15--20 minutes total to ask about Amazon and the role. While I understand the importance of some behavioral interviewing, it's not the only way to assess someone's success in the role. And you also don't know what you're walking into at Amazon because you haven't really been given the chance to ask. If I had the chance I likely would have flushed out much of what I've written above, and I would not have accepted the offer.

If you have any experience in recruiting, I'd honestly stay away. It's much too broken and while they are open to change it requires 5 papers to get anything done. They grew much too fast and didn't build out the recruiting department fast enough. Candidate experience is constantly preached, but candidates are handled so poorly (by interviewers and recruiters). This isn't a problem in every department, but when candidate experience is taught as the number one important thing, you can't let it fall by the way side as much as happens.
